biography.title: Biography
biography.paragraph1: Kirill Mikhalenko, born on September 7, 1998, in Rechitsa, Gomel Region, Belarus, hails from a family of oil industry workers. The Gomel Region is renowned for its oil deposits and extraction. Kirill uses exclusively natural materials, with paintings created using oil not only serving as artistic works but also as powerful symbols of contemporary reality. By employing this medium, Kirill aims to reveal the multifaceted aspects of our lives and society.
biography.paragraph2: Oil represents the abundance of resources that has led to economic prosperity and technological progress on one hand, but ecological disasters and social conflicts on the other. This choice of material is an attempt to visualize this paradox. Each painting serves as a reminder of how we often ignore the consequences of our actions. Using oil as a painting medium illustrates the interaction between humanity and nature. Oil, the result of millions of years of natural transformation, makes these paintings a metaphor for destruction and restoration.
biography.paragraph3: Kirill hopes viewers will see not only beauty in these works but also the necessity to reflect on and reconsider our relationship with the planet’s resources. Oil evokes strong emotions—desire, fear, or anxiety. These artworks convey this emotional tension, creating a visual dialogue about what it means to be part of a world filled with contradictions. The goal is to provoke reflection on how each of us contributes to the existing system and its impact on the world around us. Thus, each oil painting becomes a multilayered work, laden with meaning and calling for contemplation.
